title: How to Overcome Nausea at Night

steps.title: Try acupressure.
steps.content: Try acupressure . Targeting the pressure point that eases motion sickness can keep nausea away. This point is the Pericardium 6 (PC6), located on your wrist. Find it by placing three fingers at the crease of your wrist with your palm up. This area on the inside of your arm/wrist can be targeted through pressure from your fingers.

steps.title: Use motion sickness bands.
steps.content: Use motion sickness bands. These bands, designed to use acupressure to keep you from experiencing motion sickness, are often available at drugstores or travel stores. They are typically a small sweatband that goes around your wrist at the PC6 with a half of a small ball attached to keep constant pressure. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Use aromatherapy oils.
steps.content: Use aromatherapy oils. Lavender and peppermint are those most associated with calming the stomach and helping nausea. You can use them as essential oils and put them on your wrists, or on a soothing face mask. You could also try them as candle scents.

steps.title: Avoid strong smells.
steps.content: Avoid strong smells. Sometimes there are particular smells that can trigger nausea. These might be from food, strong perfume, or rotting or decaying smells. Keep your area well-ventilated (particularly the kitchen and eating area) to combat this. [3] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Attempt to eat the BRAT diet.
steps.content: Attempt to eat the BRAT diet. Bananas, rice, applesauce, and toast are the foods that have been proven to help prevent diarrhea, but can also help symptoms of nausea and vomiting. The BRAT diet is not meant to be used long-term, as it does not provide necessary nutrients to your body. Once your nausea has subsided, you should start adding in fresh fruits and vegetables and then return to your normal diet. [4] X Trustworthy Source FamilyDoctor.org Family-focused medical advice site run by the American Academy of Family Doctors Go to source

steps.title: Try bland foods.
steps.content: Try bland foods. If the BRAT diet is too restrictive, you can add bland foods into the mix. [5] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Nausea can often be made worse by spicy foods. Even if food doesn’t sound good, attempt to eat some saltine crackers or bread to try and help settle your stomach.

steps.title: Eat long before bedtime.
steps.content: Eat long before bedtime. Eating right before you lay down to sleep can increase nausea. [6] X Expert Source Peter Gardner, MD Board Certified Gastroenterologist Expert Interview. 25 August 2020. Give yourself enough time to fully digest your meal before sleep. Eating close to bedtime can also increase the possibility of heartburn. [7] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Choose multiple small meals a day.
steps.content: Choose multiple small meals a day. Even if your nausea typically occurs at night, eating more frequent, small meals can help prevent nausea. Keeping your stomach mostly full might also help prevent nausea from becoming more severe.

steps.title: Stay away from foods that are greasy, fatty, or spicy.
steps.content: Stay away from foods that are greasy, fatty, or spicy. [8] X Expert Source Peter Gardner, MD Board Certified Gastroenterologist Expert Interview. 25 August 2020. These tend to exacerbate nausea. Your body can also have more difficulty processing these foods. It’s best to aim for light and healthy foods (fresh fruits and vegetables) that can keep your body working smoothly.

steps.title: Drink lots of water.
steps.content: Drink lots of water. Staying well-hydrated is one of the most important steps to take when combating nausea. [9] X Expert Source Peter Gardner, MD Board Certified Gastroenterologist Expert Interview. 25 August 2020. Try drinking an extra 16 oz of water beyond what you normally drink at night. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Try tea.
steps.content: Try tea. Many doctors recommend ginger or peppermint tea as a remedy for nausea. The teas and their scents can help calm your stomach. You can also try either flavor in different forms — ginger in foods is common, and peppermint candies can also help.

steps.title: See if carbonated beverages help.
steps.content: See if carbonated beverages help. Many people find that the bubbles of carbonation can help an upset stomach. Choose ginger ale or citrus-flavored carbonated beverages. Use sparingly, since soda is not very healthy. A small glass can sometimes help, often coupled with some crackers or other bland food. [11] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Try doctor-prescribed medicine.
steps.content: Try doctor-prescribed medicine. Some nausea is only going to respond to medication. [12] X Expert Source Peter Gardner, MD Board Certified Gastroenterologist Expert Interview. 25 August 2020. Follow the treatment regimen described by your doctor. Watch for side effects — many anti-nausea medications cause drowsiness. [13] X Research source Prochlorperazine is the most commonly used anti-nausea medication. It is moderately effective for nausea and other GI disorders, but not as effective for chemotherapy-induced nausea. Metoclopramide and ondansetron are two other anti-nausea medications your doctor may prescribe. Always follow your doctor's instructions on dosage and duration of medication.

steps.title: Consider marijuana if it's legal.
steps.content: Consider marijuana if it's legal. If you live in a state where medical marijuana is legal, chances are that many doctors prescribe it for the nausea that can accompany chemotherapy. Many studies have shown that it can be an effective treatment for nausea. Keep in mind that marijuana comes in many forms — a candy or other edible form might be a good choice. Talk to your medical professional about a possible prescription. Unfavorable side effects of include vertigo, dry mouth, low blood pressure, and depression.

steps.title: Go to the doctor for severe recurring nausea.
steps.content: Go to the doctor for severe recurring nausea. If you have experienced nausea for over a month and if your vomiting has lasted more than two days, you should see your doctor. Also go if you have unexplained weight loss. Your doctor will be able to help you, and might include a different diet or even medication. [14] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Monitor your symptoms.
steps.content: Monitor your symptoms. Extreme nausea coupled with other symptoms might mean you need to take a trip as soon as possible to your doctor or a clinic. Take prompt action if nausea is accompanied by: [15] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Chest pains High fever Cramping Fecal odor in your vomit Fainting Confusion Blurred vision You can keep a vomiting diary if you have cyclic vomiting syndrome. [16] X Expert Source Roy Nattiv, MD Board Certified Gastroenterologist Expert Interview. 14 October 2020. Note the triggers for the vomiting episodes, such as the things you ate, drinks you took, or the activities you engaged in before the episode. [17] X Expert Source Roy Nattiv, MD Board Certified Gastroenterologist Expert Interview. 14 October 2020. Anxiety can also cause vomiting episodes. [18] X Expert Source Roy Nattiv, MD Board Certified Gastroenterologist Expert Interview. 14 October 2020.

steps.title: Seek immediate medical attention for some symptoms coupled with nausea.
steps.content: Seek immediate medical attention for some symptoms coupled with nausea. This would mean a trip to the emergency room or an immediate appointment at your doctor’s office. Watch for these symptoms, together with nausea, because they can be serious. Pain or a headache (like you’ve never had before) You can’t keep food or drink down for 12 hours Your vomit is green, bloody, or looks like coffee grounds You have symptoms of dehydration (extreme thirst, dark urine, dizziness, etc.)
